#Text=Make Pan De Yuca
#Text=Pan de
#Text=Yuca is a traditional South American cheese bread that is made commonly in Ecuador and Colombia .
#Text=This bread is made with yuca flour ( also known as cassava or tapioca flour ) , which is a gluten-free starch extracted from the cassava root .
#Text=Pan de Yuca is also often paired with a traditional fruit and yogurt smoothie .
#Text=There is even an entire restaurant chain in Ecuador called Naturissimo , which is dedicated to the " pan de yuca con yogurt " combination .

column1: #Text=However , you can easily make this to enjoy at home .
#Text=Ingredients
#Text=Pan de Yuca
#Text=1 cup yuca flour
#Text=1 teaspoon baking powder
#Text=2 cups shredded queso blanco ( or any other white cheese , such as mozzarella or Oaxaca cheese )
#Text=2 egg yolks
#Text=2 tablespoons melted butter
#Text=2-3 tablespoons heavy cream ( or milk )
#Text=Yogurt Smoothie
#Text=2 cups ice
#Text=1/2 cup plain yogurt
#Text=1 cup chopped fruit of choice
#Text=2 tablespoons sugar ( optional )
#Text=Steps
#Text=Making Pan de Yuca
#Text=Preheat oven to .
#Text=Line a baking sheet with aluminum foil and lightly grease with cooking spray .
#Text=Set aside for now .
#Text=Combine yuca flour and baking powder in a large bowl .
#Text=Mix the ingredients together using a fork until they are evenly mixed .
#Text=Add cheese to the bowl .
#Text=Using the same fork , mix the cheese in with the flour mixture until everything in the bowl is mixed evenly together .
#Text=Beat egg yolks .
#Text=In a separate bowl , lightly beat the egg yolks , and then add them to the mixture in the large bowl .
#Text=Stir the ingredients together until mixture is even .
#Text=The mixture should now appear light yellow and chunky .
#Text=Add melted butter .
#Text=Mix well .
#Text=This should make the mixture slightly more clumpy , but it will likely still be too dry to form a ball of dough .
#Text=Add heavy cream .
#Text=Do this by mixing in one tablespoon at a time , until mixture is dense enough to roll into a ball .
#Text=This may also be substituted for milk , following the same instructions as for the cream , but will result in a slightly less dense bread .
#Text=Remove mixture from the bowl and knead on a floured surface until completely smooth .
#Text=Note that it will still appear chunky even when the dough is smooth because the cheese will give it a bumpier texture .
#Text=Divide dough into ten even parts and roll them into balls .
#Text=Place these on the baking sheet at least one inch apart from each other so that they have room to expand as they bake .
#Text=Place the baking sheet in the oven .
#Text=Bake for 10-15 minutes , or until the bottoms appear golden brown .
#Text=Note that pan de yuca is a very pale bread , so it will not appear as golden-brown as many other baked goods do when they are finished .
#Text=Poke a toothpick into the bread to check for doneness if needed .
#Text=Yogurt Smoothie
#Text=Add chopped fruit and yogurt to blender .
#Text=Blend the fruit and yogurt together until the mixture is smooth and consistent .
#Text=Add ice and blend .
#Text=Blend the ice into the fruit and yogurt mixture to thicken the texture and chill the drink .
#Text=It may help to crush the ice into smaller pieces before blending , depending on the strength of your blender , to prevent it from getting jammed .
#Text=Add sugar ( optional ) .
#Text=If you wish to sweeten the flavor of the fruit , add sugar and blend well .
#Text=Serve in a glass and enjoy with warm Pan de Yuca .
#Text=You may want to try dipping the bread into the yogurt smoothie and taking a bite , as is traditionally done .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Yuca flour can be found at a local Hispanic grocery store , and sometimes at other stores with international grocery sections .
#Text=Queso blanco is a typical Caribbean white cheese which can be found at Costco , Walmart , and Hispanic grocery stores .
#Text=Do not hesitate to use combinations of two or more cheeses in your bread .
#Text=Just make sure to use the same total amount of cheese in the bread for similar results .
